Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a laser-ablation, multi-collector ICP-MS for research and training in Earth, Environmental, and Anthropological Sciences
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will permit the acquisition of a multi-collector, inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometer coupled with a laser ablation system (LA-MC-ICPMS) for research, education, and training in Earth, Environmental, and Anthropological Sciences at Washington State University. The instrumentation will be utilized in diverse applications by a team of researchers seeking to address problems across a wide spectrum of scientific disciplines including geochemistry, geochronology, petrology, volcanology, tectonics, fish ecology, archeology, and anthropology. The LA-MC-ICPMS will be housed in the existing ICP-MS laboratory within the GeoAnalytical Laboratory (GAL) in the School of the Environment. This laboratory has not only provided data and research training for students and faculty at WSU, but has also served as an analytical center, supporting the research needs of many outside users.

Fundamental research problems to be addressed include chemical evolution of the Earth, geochronology of metamorphic processes, models for mountain belt formation and deformation, salmon migration and life history, and ancient human migration and trade. The instrument will allow improved access to a wide range of isotope systems and methods: zircon Hf isotope geochemistry by LA-MC-ICPMS and solution MC-ICPMS; zircon U-Pb geochronology by LA-ICPMS; whole-rock Hf, Nd, Pb and Sr isotope geochemistry; Lu-Hf and Sm-Nd garnet, lawsonite and apatite geochronology; Sr isotope analysis by LA-MC-ICPMS on minerals, fish otoliths, and archeological artifacts; and laser ablation split stream (LASS) techniques including U-Pb and Hf isotopes in zircon and U-Pb and Nd isotopes in monazite and other accessory minerals.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of this proposal was to fund a multicollector (MC) inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometer (ICPMS) and associated laser ablation (LA) system to be housed in the Radiogenic Isotope and Geochronology Laboratory (RIGL) in the School of the Environment at Washington State University. After this proposal was funded we purchased a Neptune Plus MC-ICPMS from ThermoScientific and an Analyte Excite excimer 193nm laser ablation system from Teledyne Instruments. To prepare for the new instrumentation we renovated a new laboratory space to house these instruments. We also moved an existing high resolution ICPMS (Element2 from ThermoScientific) to complete the laboratory. This array of instruments in the new laboratory (shown in the accompanying image) is being utilized to address diverse scientific problems in the fields of Earth, Environmental, and Anthropological Sciences by researchers at Washington State University and the University of Idaho as well as members of the broader national and international community that regularly utilize our laboratory. The techniques developed in the Radiogenic Isotope and Geochronology Laboratory (RIGL), in which this instrumentation plays a pivotal role, has broad interest within the fields of Earth, Environmental, and Anthropological Sciences.  Some examples include: Hf, Nd, Sr, and Pb isotope analysis of purified solutions by MC-ICPMS to understand the origin and evolution of the planet Earth; Lu-Hf and Sm-Nd garnet geochronology by MC-ICPMS to provide understanding of the timing of mountain building events; U-Pb zircon geochronology by LA-ICPMS to determine ages of rocks and minerals; trace element analysis by LA-ICPMS to use geochemistry to understand the formation of rocks and minerals; Lu-Hf analysis of zircon by LA-MC-ICPMS for use as a tracer to understand the origins of rocks and minerals; Sr isotope analysis by LA-MC-ICPMS for use to understand magmatic evolution and also as a tracer of fish, animal, and people migration; U-Pb and Lu-Hf analysis of zircon by the Laser Ablation Split Stream (LASS) technique (simultaneous analysis using laser ablation connected with both the MC-ICPMS and HR-ICPMS) to link the age and tracer Hf isotope signatures of a mineral in a single analysis; U-Pb and Sm-Nd isotope analysis of monazite, titanite, and other REE rich phases by the LASS technique to link the age and tracer Nd isotope signatures of a mineral in a single analysis.   For many of these techniques we have been among the world leaders and freely disseminate information on these techniques through publications, scientific presentations, and through visiting researchers who come to the RIGL to conduct their research.  In sum, this laboratory will contribute to fundamental knowledge on a broad range of topics from the formation and evolution of our planet from its very beginnings to the migrations of animals and people in the recent and present-day Earth.
